title: If I like classical music what should I know about it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Listen. Lots. Try composers from different eras and styles. You’ll like some of it, hate some of it, and feel “meh” about others. Pretty soon, you’ll figure out what composers you like and want to delve further into. FWIW, I started getting into classical when I was about 12 and my parents got me a record (yes, I’m that old, an actual LP) of Rimsky-Korsakov’s “Scheherazade.” And I was amazed to find out that not only was it beautiful music, it told a story — without words! A lot of years later: I have a huge collection of classical music. Plus, I’ve studied classical flute and piano, and while I’m nowhere near good enough to be a professional musician or anything, it’s given me another lens into how music is structured. An interesting side note: I have a friend who is a college professor of music theory. She’s forgotten more about music than I’ll ever know. Anyhow, we were talking about musical taste, and I said that I liked music from very different composers, from different eras, and disliked others, but could never figure out what the commonality was between the ones I liked. So she asked me for some examples. I said some of my favorites were J. S. Bach, a lot of Renaissance composers (Tallis, Palestrina, Susato, and Praetorius, especially)… and Shostakovich and Prokofiev. She smiled. “I bet you don’t like Mozart much,” she said. “Not really. I like a few pieces, but most of it’s pleasant background music and not much more, in my opinion. But how did you know that?” “It’s rhythm,” she said. “You like odd cross rhythms and interesting unexpected chord progressions. That’s what’s common to all of the ones you like. Mozart, for all of his genius at composing beautiful melodies, didn’t rely on surprising rhythms or odd chords very much. But I’ll make you a bet, okay?” I asked her what. She said, “Listen to the first movement of Mozart’s 25th Symphony. I bet you lunch that you’ll love it.” I ended up buying her lunch. Take a listen.

You don’t need to know anything about it. Just enjoy the music - that is what it’s for. But as you hear more, you’ll inevitably learn more about it - who you like, who you don’t, the history, the instrumentation. I think knowing something about it enhances the music in some ways, because every piece has some little bit of history (or at least a story) behind it, and fits into a bigger picture to varying degrees. But you’ll pick it up. If you happen to live in Australia, or can access it via the web, ABC Classic FM is a great station for learning about classical music, because they explain a lot about what they play, and have programs such as ‘Keys To Music’, which is perfect for the average person who wants to learn more. You could also try BBC Radio 3. I also recommend going to live concerts - it’s a completely different experience than listening to a recording, no matter how good your sound equipment. For example, the first time I heard Saint-Saëns 3rd symphony played on a really enormous orchestral organ (at the Albert Hall), it was like being allowed a glimpse of another dimension - even recalling the experience 25 years later makes the hairs on my neck stand up!
